text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

My parents used
to always tell me

a quote from Danny Thomas, the
founder of St. Jude Children's
Research Hospital.
"There are two types of people--
the givers and the takers.

The takers usually eat
better, but the givers always
sleep better."

Growing up as a son of
two Lebanese immigrants,

I learned the importance
of being a giver

through the decades of
civil war and destruction
that my family faced.

My family always maintained
an unwavering support

and dedication to giving back
to Lebanon and to the people
that we love.

This identity as the giver
has made me who I am today.

And from a young age, I
relished in the feeling

of giving back both
to my community
here in the US and abroad.

Luckily, it didn't take
long for my passion

for giving to run
into my tendencies

for entrepreneurship,
as in middle school,

I found myself selling
discounted snacks out
of my locker.

And in high school, I
established a landscaping
repair company.

During my undergrad,
I realized that I

could leverage both my giver
and entrepreneurial spirit

through my involvement in
St. Jude Children's Research

Hospital, and after graduation,
through my involvement

in helping engineer
electric vehicles.

Through these
experiences, I've realized

that life's purpose
is in finding

what you're passionate about and
utilizing that to help others.

I've realized that my life
purpose is in developing

technology solutions,
especially for those
in the face of adversity.

I've learned that
success in life

has nothing to do with what
we accomplish for ourselves,

but rather what
we do for others.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
